title: Rental Supply Shortage Drives U.K. Rents to New Records and is Expected to Worsen
text:
Renters across Great Britain are forking out more than ever for their homes, according to a report Thursday from Rightmove.



Both in the capital city of London and in wider Great Britain, monthly rents reached record peaks in the third quarter, the online real estate portal said.



More: London Townhouse Where Mozart Composed First Symphony Listed for £7.5 Million

London values led the charge, where monthly asking rents increased 5.6% in the third quarter compared to the same time last year, leaving them at an average of £2,104 (US$2,708).



Across the rest of Great Britain—excluding London—asking rents grew 3.2% to an average of £828 over the same time.



In fact, asking rents hit record highs almost across the board. The only two regions not to reach new peaks were Scotland and the North East of England, according to the report.



Driving the increase in prices is a lack of rental inventory due to tax changes deterring new and existing landlords, Rightmove said.



In 2016, landlords faced the introduction of a 3% surcharge to the stamp duty tax for second and buy-to-let home purchases.



Then in 2017, the U.K. began effectively increasing taxes on landlords by phasing out a mortgage interest deduction on buy-to-let properties. The deduction has been lowered by 25% each year since, and will be eliminated next year.

Nationally, the number of rental properties available in the third quarter was 13% under the previous low recorded in 2015. In London, listings dropped 24% in the same time.



But despite the increasing rents, more landlords are still planning on shrinking their portfolios, Rightmove said.



Almost a quarter of landlords, 24%, are planning to sell at least one of their rental properties in the future, the report said.



A cause of concern for tenants are “signs that the stock shortage may worsen if some landlords follow through with their plans to sell up, though an increase in plans for build-to-rent properties may help to fill some of the gap,” said Miles Shipside, commercial director and housing market analyst at Rightmove.



“The overall feeling among those landlords who are planning to exit the market is one of frustration with many telling us that the tax changes mean it’s no longer financially attractive to keep their properties,” he said.
